revisions.rev:
This is a list of all spacecraft '''landings on other planets and bodies''' in the solar system, including [[Soft landing (rocketry)|soft landings]] and both intended and unintended [[Hard landing|hard impacts]]. The list includes orbiters that were intentionally crashed, but not orbiters which later crashed in an unplanned manner due to orbit decay. For a list of all planetary missions, including orbiters and flybys, see [[List of Solar System probes]]. ==[[Moon]] (not a planet)== {{main|Moon landings}} {|class = wikitable width="100%" |- valign="top" ! style="text-align:left" width="20%" | '''Mission''' ! style="text-align:left" width="10%" | '''Country/Agency''' ! style="text-align:left" width="15%" | '''Date of landing/impact''' ! style="text-align:left" width="15%" | '''Coordinates''' ! style="text-align:left" width="40%" | '''Notes''' |- valign="top" |[[Luna 2]] || {{flagicon|USSR}} USSR || 13 September 1959 || {{Lunar coords and quad cat|29.1|N|0|W}} || First lunar impact. |- valign="top" |[[Ranger 4]] || {{flagicon|USA}} USA || 26 April 1962 || {{Lunar coords and quad cat|15.5|S|229.3|E}} || Intentional hard impact; hit lunar far side due to failure of navigation system. |- valign="top" |[[Ranger 6]] || {{flagicon|USA}} USA || 2 February 1964 || {{Lunar coords and quad cat|9.4|N|21.5|E}} || Intentional hard impact. |- valign="top" |[[Ranger 7]] || {{flagicon|USA}} USA || 31 July 1964 || {{Lunar coords and quad cat|10.35|S|339.42|E}} || Intentional hard impact. |- valign="top" |[[Ranger 8]] || {{flagicon|USA}} USA || 20 February 1965 || {{Lunar coords and quad cat|2.72|N|24.61|E}} || Intentional hard impact. |- valign="top" |[[Ranger 9]] || {{flagicon|USA}} USA || 24 March 1965 || {{Lunar coords and quad cat|12.83|S|357.63|E}} || Intentional hard impact. |- valign="top" |[[Luna 5]] || {{flagicon|USSR}} USSR || 12 May 1965 || {{Lunar coords and quad cat|31|S|8|W}} || Unsuccessful attempt at soft landing; crashed into Moon. |- valign="top" |[[Luna 7]] || {{flagicon|USSR}} USSR || 7 October 1965 || {{Lunar coords and quad cat|9.8|N|47.8|W}} || Unsuccessful attempt at soft landing; crashed into Moon. |- valign="top" |[[Luna 8]] || {{flagicon|USSR}} USSR || 6 December 1965 || {{Lunar coords and quad cat|9.6|N|62|W}} || Unsuccessful attempt at soft landing; crashed into Moon. |- valign="top" |[[Luna 9]] || {{flagicon|USSR}} USSR || 3 February 1966 || {{Lunar coords and quad cat|7.13|N|64.37|W}} || First successful soft landing; first pictures from the surface. |- valign="top" |[[Surveyor 1]] || {{flagicon|USA}} USA || 2 June 1966 || || Soft landing. |- valign="top" |[[Surveyor 2]] || {{flagicon|USA}} USA || 23 September 1966 || || Unsuccessful attempt at soft landing; crashed into Moon. |- valign="top" |[[Lunar Orbiter 1]] || {{flagicon|USA}} USA || 29 October 1966 || || Lunar orbiter, intentionally crashed at end of mission. |- valign="top" |[[Luna 13]] || {{flagicon|USSR}} USSR || 24 December 1966 || || Soft landing. |- valign="top" |[[Surveyor 3]] || {{flagicon|USA}} USA || 20 April 1967 || || Soft landing. First lander visited by a later manned mission ([[Apollo 12]]). |- valign="top" |[[Surveyor 4]] || {{flagicon|USA}} USA || 17 July 1967 || || Contact lost on descent. |- valign="top" |[[Surveyor 5]] || {{flagicon|USA}} USA || 11 September 1967 || || Soft landing. |- valign="top" |[[Surveyor 6]] || {{flagicon|USA}} USA || 10 November 1967 || || Soft landing. |- valign="top" |[[Surveyor 7]] || {{flagicon|USA}} USA || 10 January 1968 || || Soft landing. |- valign="top" |[[Apollo 11]] || {{flagicon|USA}} USA || 20 July 1969 || {{coord|0|40|26.69|N|23|28|22.69|E|globe:moon_type:landmark}} || First manned landing. |- valign="top" |[[Luna 15]] || {{flagicon|USSR}} USSR || 21 July 1969 || || Possible attempted sample return; crashed into Moon. |- valign="top" |[[Apollo 12]] || {{flagicon|USA}} USA || 18 November 1969 || {{Lunar coords and quad cat|3.012389|S|23.421569|W}} || Manned mission. |- valign="top" |[[Apollo 13]] || {{flagicon|USA}} USA || 14 April 1970 || || [[S-IVB]] stage crashed for seismic research (rocket stages from a number of other Apollo missions that successfully landed were also crashed in this manner[http://science.nasa.gov/headlines/y2006/28apr_skyisfalling.htm "The Sky is Falling"], NASA, April 28, 2006) |- valign="top" |[[Luna 16]] || {{flagicon|USSR}} USSR || 20 September 1970 || || First successful robotic sample return. |- valign="top" |[[Luna 17]]/[[Lunokhod 1]] || {{flagicon|USSR}} USSR || 17 November 1970 || || Robotic lunar [[rover (space exploration)|rover]]. |- valign="top" |[[Apollo 14]] || {{flagicon|USA}} USA || 5 February 1971 || {{Coord|3|38|43.08|S|17|28|16.90|W|globe:moon}}|| Manned mission. |- valign="top" |[[Apollo 15]] || {{flagicon|USA}} USA || 30 July 1971 ||{{coord|26|7|55.99|N|3|38|1.90|E|type:landmark_globe:moon|name=Apollo 15 landing}} || Manned mission; lunar rover. |- valign="top" |[[Luna 18]] || {{flagicon|USSR}} USSR || 11 September 1971 || || Failed attempt at sample return; probable crash-landing. |- valign="top" |[[Luna 20]] || {{flagicon|USSR}} USSR || 21 February 1972 || || Robotic sample return. |- valign="top" |[[Apollo 16]] || {{flagicon|USA}} USA || 21 April 1972 ||{{coord|8|58|22.84|S|15|30|0.68|E|type:landmark_globe:moon}} || Manned mission; lunar rover. |- valign="top" |[[Apollo 17]] || {{flagicon|USA}} USA || 7 December 1972 ||{{Coord|20|11|26.88|N|30|46|18.05|E|globe:moon|name=Apollo 17 landing}} || Manned mission; lunar rover. |- valign="top" |[[Luna 21]]/[[Lunokhod 2]] || {{flagicon|USSR}} USSR || 8 January 1973 || || Robotic lunar [[rover (space exploration)|rover]]. |- valign="top" |[[Luna 23]] || {{flagicon|USSR}} USSR || 6 November 1974 || || Failed attempt at sample return; damaged on landing. |- valign="top" |[[Luna 24]] || {{flagicon|USSR}} USSR || 18 August 1976 || || Robotic sample return. |- valign="top" |[[Hiten]] || {{flagicon|JPN}} Japan || 10 April 1993 || || Lunar orbiter, intentionally crashed at end of mission. |- valign="top" |[[Lunar Prospector]] || {{flagicon|USA}} USA || 31 July 1999 || {{Lunar coords and quad cat|87.7|S|42.1|E}} || Lunar orbiter, intentionally crashed into polar crater at end of mission to test for liberation of water vapour (not detected). |- valign="top" |[[SMART-1]] || [[Image:Not the esa logo.png|24px]] [[European Space Agency|ESA]] || 3 September 2006 || || Lunar orbiter, intentionally crashed at end of mission. |- valign="top" |[[Chandrayaan-1]] [[Moon Impact Probe]] || {{flagicon|India}} [[ISRO]] || 14 November 2008 || || Impactor. |- valign="top" | [[SELENE#Okina (small relay satellite)|SELENE Rstar (Okina)]]|| {{flag|Japan}}|| 12 February 2009 || || Lunar orbiter, casually crashed at end of mission. |- valign="top" | [[Chang'e 1]]|| {{flag|China}}|| 1 March 2009 || || Lunar orbiter, intentionally crashed at end of mission. |- valign="top" | [[SELENE|Kaguya]]|| {{flag|Japan}}|| 10 June 2009 || || Lunar orbiter, intentionally crashed at end of mission. |- valign="top" |[[LCROSS]] (Centaur) | rowspan="2" | {{flag|USA}} | rowspan="2" | 9 October, 2009 | rowspan="2" | {{coord|84.675|S|311.275|E|type:landmark_globe:moon}}
{{coord|84.729|S|310.64|E|type:landmark_globe:moon}} | rowspan="2" | Impactors. Water found. |- valign="top" | LCROSS (Shepherding Spacecraft) |} ==[[Venus]]== {|class = wikitable width="100%" |- valign="top" ! style="text-align:left" width="20%" | '''Mission''' ! style="text-align:left" width="10%" | '''Country/Agency''' ! style="text-align:left" width="15%" | '''Date of landing/impact''' ! style="text-align:left" width="15%" | '''Coordinates''' ! style="text-align:left" width="40%" | '''Notes''' |- valign="top" |[[Venera 3]] || {{flagicon|USSR}} USSR || 1 March 1966 || Probably around -20Â° to 20Â° N, 60Â° to 80Â° E || First impact on the surface of another planet. Contact lost before atmospheric entry. |- valign="top" |[[Venera 4]] || {{flagicon|USSR}} USSR || 18 October 1967 || Estimated near {{Venus coords and quad cat|19|N|38|E}}.{{cite book|pages=98â101|title=Russian planetary exploration|author=Brian Harvey|url=http://books.google.com/booksid=jKmIclMIwPAC&pg=PA101|publisher=Springer|year=2007|isbn=0387463437}} || Crushed by atmospheric pressure before impact. |- valign="top" |[[Venera 5]] || {{flagicon|USSR}} USSR || 16 May 1969 || {{Venus coords and quad cat|3|S|18|E}} || Atmospheric probe; crushed by atmospheric pressure before impact. |- valign="top" |[[Venera 6]] || {{flagicon|USSR}} USSR || 17 May 1969 || {{Venus coords and quad cat|5|S|23|E}} || Atmospheric probe; crushed by atmospheric pressure before impact. |- valign="top" |[[Venera 7]] || {{flagicon|USSR}} USSR || 15 December 1970 || {{Venus coords and quad cat|5|S|351|E}} || First successful soft landing on another planet; transmitted from surface for 23 minutes. |- valign="top" |[[Venera 8]] || {{flagicon|USSR}} USSR || 22 July 1972 || Within 150 km radius of {{Venus coords and quad cat|10.70|S|335.25|E}} || Soft landing; transmitted from surface for 50 minutes. |- valign="top" |[[Venera 9| Venera 9 lander]] || {{flagicon|USSR}} USSR || 22 October 1975 || Within a 150 km radius of {{Venus coords and quad cat|31.01|N|291.64|E}} || Soft landing; transmitted from surface for 53 minutes. First pictures from surface. |- valign="top" |[[Venera 10| Venera 10 lander]] || {{flagicon|USSR}} USSR || 25 October 1975 || Within a 150 km radius of {{Venus coords and quad cat|15.42|N|291.51|E}}) || Soft landing; transmitted from surface for 65 minutes. |- valign="top" |[[Pioneer Venus Multiprobe]] || {{flagicon|USA}} USA || 9 December 1978 || Surviving "Day Probe" landed at
{{Venus coords and quad cat|31.3|S|317.0|E}} || One of four atmospheric probes survived impact and continued to transmit for 67 minutes. |- valign="top" |[[Venera 12| Venera 12 lander]] || {{flagicon|USSR}} USSR || 21 December 1978 || {{Venus coords and quad cat|7|S|294|E}} || Soft landing; transmitted from surface for 110 minutes. |- valign="top" |[[Venera 11| Venera 11 lander]] || {{flagicon|USSR}} USSR || 25 December 1978 || {{Venus coords and quad cat|14|S|299|E}} || Soft landing; transmitted from surface for 95 minutes. |- valign="top" |[[Venera 13| Venera 13 lander]] || {{flagicon|USSR}} USSR || 1 March 1982 || {{Venus coords and quad cat|7.5|S|303|E}} || Soft landing; transmitted from surface for 127 minutes. |- valign="top" |[[Venera 14| Venera 14 lander]] || {{flagicon|USSR}} USSR || 5 March 1982 || {{Venus coords and quad cat|13.25|S|310|E}} || Soft landing; transmitted from surface for 57 minutes. |- valign="top" |[[Vega 1| Vega 1 lander]] || {{flagicon|USSR}} USSR || 11 June 1985 || {{Venus coords and quad cat|7.2|N|177.8|E}} || Soft landing; instruments failed to return data. |- valign="top" |[[Vega 2| Vega 2 lander]] || {{flagicon|USSR}} USSR || 15 June 1985 || {{Venus coords and quad cat|7.14|S|177.67|E}} || Soft landing; transmitted from surface for 57 minutes. |} ==[[Mars]]== {|class = wikitable width="100%" |- valign="top" ! style="text-align:left" width="20%" | '''Mission''' ! style="text-align:left" width="10%" | '''Country/Agency''' ! style="text-align:left" width="15%" | '''Date of landing/impact''' ! style="text-align:left" width="15%" | '''Coordinates''' ! style="text-align:left" width="40%" | '''Notes''' |- valign="top" |[[Mars 2| Mars 2 lander]] || {{flagicon|USSR}} USSR || 27 November 1971 || {{Coord|45|S|30|W|globe:Mars_type:landmark}} || First man-made object on Mars. No contact after crash landing. |- valign="top" |[[Mars 3| Mars 3 lander]] || {{flagicon|USSR}} USSR || 2 December 1971 || {{Coord|45|S|158|W|globe:Mars_type:landmark}} || First soft landing on Mars. First images from surface{{cite web|url=http://www.svengrahn.pp.se/histind/Mars3/Mars3.html|title="Mars 3"|accessdate=2010-05-28}}.Sent signal for only 20 seconds after landing. |- valign="top" |[[Mars 6| Mars 6 lander]] || {{flagicon|USSR}} USSR || 12 March 1974 || {{Coord|23.90|S|19.42|W|globe:Mars_type:landmark}} || Contact lost at landing. |- valign="top" |[[Viking 1| Viking 1 lander]] || {{flagicon|USA}} USA || 20 July 1976 || {{Coord|22.697|N|48.222|W|globe:Mars_type:landmark}} || Successful soft landing. |- valign="top" |[[Viking 2| Viking 2 lander]] || {{flagicon|USA}} USA || 3 September 1976 || {{coord|48.269|N|225.990|W|globe:mars_type:landmark}} || Successful soft landing. |- valign="top" |[[Mars Pathfinder]] and [[Sojourner (rover)|Sojourner]] rover || {{flagicon|USA}} USA || 4 July 1997 || {{Coord|19.13|N|33.22|W|globe:Mars_type:landmark}} || First air bag landing on Mars and first Mars rover. |- valign="top" |[[Mars Polar Lander]] || {{flagicon|USA}} USA || 3 December 1999 || || Contact lost prior to landing. |- valign="top" |[[Beagle 2]] || {{flagicon|UK}} [[United Kingdom|UK]]/
[[Image:Not the esa logo.png|24px]] [[European Space Agency|ESA]] || 25 December 2003 || || No contact after landing attempt. It is not known for certain that the craft reached the Martian surface (either intact or at all[http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sciencetech/article-1021929/Life-Mars-Crystal-clear-images-best-view-red-planet.html "Life on Mars? Crystal clear images which give us our best ever view of the red planet"], ''Mail Online'', 27th May 2008). |- valign="top" |[[MER-A|MER-A 'Spirit']] || {{flagicon|USA}} USA || 3 January 2004 || {{Coord|14.5718|S|175.4785|E|globe:mars_type:landmark}} || Mars rover. |- valign="top" |[[MER-B|MER-B 'Opportunity']] || {{flagicon|USA}} USA || 25 January 2004 || {{Coord|1.95|S|354.47|E|globe:mars_type:landmark}} || Mars rover. |- valign="top" |[[Phoenix (spacecraft)|Phoenix]] || {{flagicon|USA}} USA || 25 May 2008|| {{Coord|68.218830|N|234.250778|E|globe:Mars_type:landmark}} || Landed in the north polar region, and investigated whether conditions there are suitable for life to have evolved. |} ==Other bodies== {|class = wikitable width="100%" |- valign="top" ! style="text-align:left" width="15%" | '''Body''' ! style="text-align:left" width="15%" | '''Mission''' ! style="text-align:left" width="10%" | '''Country/Agency''' ! style="text-align:left" width="15%" | '''Date of landing/impact''' ! style="text-align:left" width="15%" | '''Coordinates''' ! style="text-align:left" width="30%" | '''Notes''' |- valign="top" |[[433 Eros|Eros]] (asteroid) || {{nowrap|[[NEAR Shoemaker]]}} || {{flagicon|USA}} USA || 12 February 2001 || || Designed as an orbiter, but an improvised landing was carried out on completion of the main mission. Transmission from the surface continued for about 16 days. |- valign="top" |[[Jupiter]] || [[Galileo (spacecraft)|Galileo]] || {{nowrap|{{flagicon|USA}} USA}} || {{nowrap|7 December 1995}}
(atmospheric probe)
{{nowrap|21 September 2003}}
(main craft) || || Atmospheric probe, and, later, main craft were intentionally directed at Jupiter and disintegrated in Jovian atmosphere. [Not a "landing," but an intentional impact with a planetary body.] |- valign="top" |{{nowrap|[[Titan (moon)|Titan]] (moon of Saturn)}} || [[Huygens probe]] || [[Image:Not the esa logo.png|24px]] [[European Space Agency|ESA]]/
